overview: A 36-week AP Calculus BC course aligned to the College Board CED (2020). Covers all AB topics plus parametric/polar/vector-valued functions and infinite sequences & series. Built on an 11-unit scope and sequence (Units 0–10) with two heavyweight units (Integration 17–20%, Series 17–18%) receiving proportionally more instructional time. Every unit integrates calculator-active and no-calculator practice, FRQ-style justification writing, and graphical/tabular interpretation. Spiral review threads run through every checkpoint.
naturalProgression: Begin with Prereq Patch (Unit 0) to diagnose and repair algebra, trig, and function gaps that derail calculus learning
Establish the concept of limits and continuity (Unit 1) as the foundation for the derivative
Define the derivative through the difference quotient and build basic differentiation rules (Unit 2)
Extend differentiation to composite, implicit, and inverse functions via chain rule (Unit 3)
Apply differentiation to real-world contexts: related rates, motion, linearization, L'Hôpital (Unit 4)
Analyze functions using first/second derivative tests, concavity, EVT/MVT, and optimization (Unit 5)
Build the integral from Riemann sums through FTC Parts 1 & 2, antiderivatives, and accumulation functions (Unit 6 — heavyweight)
Solve differential equations via separation of variables and slope fields (Unit 7)
Apply integration to area, volume (disk/washer/cross-section), average value, and motion (Unit 8)
Extend to parametric, polar, and vector-valued functions with derivatives and integrals (Unit 9 — BC-exclusive)
Master infinite sequences and series, convergence tests, Taylor/Maclaurin polynomials, and error bounds (Unit 10 — heavyweight, BC-exclusive)
Synthesize all skills through comprehensive AP exam-format review and final assessment (Final Review)
spiralReviewThreads: Algebraic fluency — factoring, simplification, sign tracking, and domain awareness maintained through every checkpoint
Derivative fluency — basic through advanced differentiation rules revisited in integration and series contexts
Graphical/tabular interpretation — connecting algebraic forms to visual features in every unit (AP exam-critical)
Justification writing — FRQ-style reasoning practiced weekly: 'because f' changes sign' not just 'the function has a max'
Calculator competence — calculator-active and no-calculator skills explicitly practiced; students learn when to use and when not to use technology
Connections across representations — numerical, graphical, algebraic, and verbal representations linked throughout

apExamInfo.scoring: Each section (MC and FRQ) is 50% of the total score. BC subscore includes an AB subscore.

aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads all instruction using the gradual release model (I Do / We Do / You Do) but has full freedom to make instructional decisions. Module files provide scope, key concepts, teaching guidance, and reference problems—NOT rigid scripts. The AI decides pacing, chooses examples, adjusts scaffolding, and personalizes based on the student's skill mastery, learning profile, and real-time responses.

phases.aiRole: Build conceptual understanding before procedures. The AI introduces the BIG IDEA using real-world connections, student interests, and visual/physical analogies.
phases.studentRole: Engage with the concept, ask questions, make predictions

phases.aiRole: Model 2-3 worked examples with think-aloud reasoning. The AI selects problem difficulty based on the student's current mastery.
phases.studentRole: Observe, ask clarifying questions, identify patterns

phases.aiRole: Quick comprehension check before moving to practice. If gaps detected, the AI re-teaches before proceeding.
phases.studentRole: Explain understanding in own words, answer concept questions

phases.aiRole: Guided practice with adaptive scaffolding. Scaffolding decreases as the student demonstrates understanding.
phases.studentRole: Attempt problems with AI support, explain reasoning

phases.aiRole: Emotional and confidence assessment. Adjusts pacing and tone based on student engagement.
phases.studentRole: Reflect on confidence and comfort level

phases.aiRole: Independent practice. Minimal hints—only if the student is stuck.
Formal assessment for skill mastery using 4-Pillar criteria (accuracy, independence, transfer, retention).

aiDecisionRights: Choose which examples and problems to present (module provides reference problems, AI may generate its own)
Adjust difficulty in real-time based on student performance
Skip or extend phases based on student readiness
Re-order skills within a module if pedagogically appropriate
Generate additional practice or enrichment as needed
Use student interests and learning profile to personalize examples
Decide when to advance to the next skill or re-teach
Select teaching strategies (visual, algebraic, numerical, verbal) based on student profile
Adjust tone and pacing based on emotional signals and anxiety level

modules.title: Prerequisite Patch
modules.preview: Diagnose and repair algebra, trig, and function gaps before calculus content
essentialQuestions: Which prerequisite skills are secure and which need targeted repair?
How does function fluency (composition, inverses, transformations) directly support calculus?
Why does algebra/trig carelessness sabotage calculus performance?

lessons.title: Function Fluency
concepts: Domain and range of composed/inverse functions
lessons.teachingNotes: Diagnostic-first: assess before reteaching. Skip secure skills. Composition and inverses are used constantly in chain rule and integration.

lessons.title: Algebra Cleanup
concepts: Factoring: GCF, trinomials, difference of squares, sum/difference of cubes
Rational expressions: simplify, multiply, divide, complex fractions
Logarithm rules: product, quotient, power, change of base
lessons.teachingNotes: These are the algebra errors that kill calculus students. Short, frequent drills with immediate feedback.

lessons.title: Trig Essentials
concepts: Unit circle: exact values at standard angles
Graphs of sin, cos, tan and their key features
lessons.teachingNotes: Unit circle values must be automatic—no calculator. These feed directly into derivatives of trig functions.

lessons.title: Graph Literacy
concepts: Identify intercepts, asymptotes, end behavior from graphs
Connect algebraic representations to graphical features
lessons.teachingNotes: AP Calc is heavily graphical/tabular. Students must read graphs as fluently as equations.

modules.title: Unit 0 Diagnostic Checkpoint
modules.preview: Assess readiness for AP Calculus BC content

modules.title: Limits & Continuity
modules.preview: Evaluate limits graphically, numerically, and algebraically; analyze continuity and apply IVT
essentialQuestions: What does it mean for a function to approach a value, and how is that different from reaching it?
How do we evaluate limits when direct substitution fails?
What does continuity guarantee, and what does IVT let us conclude?

lessons.title: Limits from Graphs, Tables, and Algebra
concepts: Estimating limits from graphs and tables
Algebraic techniques: factoring, rationalizing, common denominators
lessons.teachingNotes: Start graphical/numerical before algebra. The concept must precede the computation.

lessons.title: One-Sided Limits, Infinite Limits, Limits at Infinity
concepts: When a limit does not exist (DNE)
Limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes
keyFormulas: If degree top < degree bottom → limit = 0
If degrees equal → limit = ratio of leading coefficients
If degree top > degree bottom → limit is ±∞

lessons.title: Continuity and Intermediate Value Theorem
concepts: Three conditions for continuity at a point
Types of discontinuity: removable, jump, infinite
IVT: if f is continuous on [a,b] and k is between f(a) and f(b), then f(c)=k for some c in (a,b)
lessons.teachingNotes: IVT requires JUSTIFICATION on the AP exam: name the theorem, state continuity, state the value is between f(a) and f(b).

modules.title: Unit 1 Checkpoint: Limits & Continuity
modules.preview: Assess limit evaluation, continuity analysis, and IVT justification

modules.title: Derivatives: Definition & Basic Rules
modules.preview: Define the derivative via difference quotient; apply power, constant, sum/difference rules
essentialQuestions: What does the derivative measure, and how does the difference quotient define it?
How do basic differentiation rules let us bypass the limit definition?
What does the derivative look like on a graph, and what does it tell us from a table?

lessons.title: The Derivative: Difference Quotient & Limit Definition
lessons.teachingNotes: Students must be able to USE the definition, not just recite it. AP frequently tests this.

lessons.title: Basic Differentiation Rules
concepts: Derivatives of sin x, cos x, eˣ, ln x

lessons.title: Derivatives from Graphs and Tables
concepts: Estimate f'(a) from a graph (tangent line slope)
Estimate f'(a) from a table (symmetric difference quotient)
Points where f is not differentiable: corners, cusps, vertical tangents, discontinuities
lessons.teachingNotes: AP tests derivative interpretation as much as computation. Practice reading derivative info from graphs and tables.

modules.title: Unit 2 Checkpoint: Derivatives Basics
modules.preview: Assess derivative definition, basic rules, and graphical/tabular interpretation

modules.title: Composite, Implicit, Inverse Derivatives
modules.preview: Apply product/quotient/chain rules; implicit differentiation; derivatives of inverse and inverse trig functions
essentialQuestions: Why do composite functions require the chain rule, and how does it connect to composition?
How does implicit differentiation handle equations where y isn't isolated?
What is the relationship between the derivative of a function and the derivative of its inverse?

lessons.title: The Chain Rule
concepts: Chain rule with trig, exponential, logarithmic functions
lessons.teachingNotes: This is the single most important differentiation technique. Master it thoroughly.

lessons.title: Implicit Differentiation
concepts: When and why to use implicit differentiation
Differentiating both sides with respect to x
Implicit on AP: typically finding slope at a point or horizontal/vertical tangent lines
lessons.teachingNotes: Students must remember: every time you differentiate a y-term, multiply by dy/dx.

lessons.title: Derivatives of Inverse Functions
concepts: Derivatives of inverse trig: arcsin, arccos, arctan
Applying to tables and graphs where f is given
lessons.teachingNotes: AP loves table problems: given f and f', find (f⁻¹)'(a). The formula is (f⁻¹)'(a) = 1/f'(f⁻¹(a)).

modules.title: Unit 3 Checkpoint: Advanced Derivatives
modules.preview: Assess product/quotient/chain rules, implicit differentiation, and inverse derivatives

modules.title: Contextual Applications of Differentiation
modules.preview: Related rates, motion, linearization, and L'Hôpital's Rule in real-world contexts
essentialQuestions: How do we translate a word problem into a calculus equation using related rates?
What is the relationship between position, velocity, and acceleration?
When and why does L'Hôpital's Rule apply, and what are its limitations?

lessons.title: Related Rates
concepts: Setting up: identify variables, draw diagram, write equation
Implicit differentiation with respect to time
Common setups: Pythagorean, volume, similar triangles, trig
Units and interpretation of the answer
lessons.teachingNotes: Diagram + label + units is the framework. Students who skip the setup make errors.

lessons.title: Straight-Line Motion
concepts: Position s(t), velocity v(t) = s'(t), acceleration a(t) = v'(t) = s''(t)
Speeding up: v and a have same sign. Slowing down: opposite signs

lessons.title: Linearization and Differentials
concepts: Linear approximation: L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x − a)
Using linearization to estimate function values

lessons.title: L'Hôpital's Rule
concepts: L'Hôpital: lim f/g = lim f'/g' when indeterminate
Must verify indeterminate form each time
keyFormulas: If lim f(x)/g(x) = 0/0 or ∞/∞, then lim f(x)/g(x) = lim f'(x)/g'(x)
lessons.teachingNotes: Students must VERIFY the indeterminate form before applying. AP deducts for skipping this step.

modules.title: Unit 4 Checkpoint: Contextual Differentiation
modules.preview: Assess related rates, motion, linearization, and L'Hôpital's Rule

modules.title: Analyzing Functions with Derivatives
modules.preview: First/second derivative tests, curve sketching, EVT/MVT, optimization
essentialQuestions: How does the first derivative tell us where a function increases, decreases, and has extrema?
What additional information does the second derivative provide about the shape of a graph?
How do EVT and MVT guarantee existence of specific values, and why does that matter?

lessons.title: Increasing/Decreasing & Extrema
concepts: Critical points: f'(x) = 0 or f'(x) DNE
First derivative test: sign change analysis
Increasing where f' > 0, decreasing where f' < 0
lessons.teachingNotes: Students must JUSTIFY with sign changes, not just state the answer. AP requires reasoning.

lessons.title: Concavity & Inflection Points
concepts: Concave up: f'' > 0, concave down: f'' < 0
Second derivative test for local extrema
lessons.teachingNotes: The f/f'/f'' connection is THE most tested relationship on the AP exam.

lessons.title: Curve Sketching from Derivative Information
concepts: Sketch f given f' or f'' graph
Identify all key features from derivative analysis
Combine first and second derivative information
lessons.teachingNotes: This is where all the pieces come together. Practice with graphs of f' → features of f.

lessons.title: Extreme Value Theorem & Mean Value Theorem
concepts: EVT: continuous function on [a,b] must have absolute max and min
Candidates test: evaluate f at critical points and endpoints
MVT: if f is continuous on [a,b] and differentiable on (a,b), there exists c where f'(c) = [f(b)−f(a)]/(b−a)
Geometric meaning: some tangent is parallel to the secant
lessons.teachingNotes: MVT is tested every year. Students must state hypotheses (continuous, differentiable) in their justification.

lessons.title: Optimization
concepts: Setting up: identify quantity to optimize, write as function of one variable
Find critical points, test with first or second derivative
Verify absolute max/min on closed interval or justify with FDT/SDT on open
lessons.teachingNotes: Setup is harder than the calculus. Practice translating geometry and word problems into optimization.

modules.title: Unit 5 Checkpoint: Function Analysis
modules.preview: Assess derivative analysis, curve sketching, MVT/EVT, and optimization

modules.title: Integration & Accumulation of Change
modules.preview: Riemann sums, definite integrals, FTC Parts 1 & 2, antiderivatives, accumulation functions
essentialQuestions: How do Riemann sums approximate the area under a curve, and what happens as n → ∞?
What are the two parts of the Fundamental Theorem, and how do they connect differentiation and integration?
How does an accumulation function represent the net change of a quantity over time?
What additional integration techniques (by parts, partial fractions) does BC require beyond AB?

lessons.title: Riemann Sums & Approximation
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect to area visually first. Over/under estimates based on increasing/decreasing and concavity.

lessons.title: Definite Integrals & Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
concepts: Definite integral as limit of Riemann sums
FTC Part 1 with chain rule: d/dx[∫ₐ^g(x) f(t)dt] = f(g(x))·g'(x)

lessons.title: Antiderivatives & u-Substitution
concepts: Basic antiderivative rules (reverse of derivative rules)
Definite integrals with u-sub (change bounds or back-substitute)

lessons.title: Integration by Parts (BC)
lessons.teachingNotes: BC-exclusive technique. LIATE (Log, Inverse trig, Algebraic, Trig, Exponential) guides u selection.

lessons.title: Partial Fraction Decomposition (BC)
concepts: Decomposing rational expressions with linear (non-repeating) factors
Recognizing when partial fractions is the right technique
lessons.teachingNotes: BC only tests non-repeating linear factors. Keep it focused.

lessons.title: Improper Integrals (BC)
concepts: Type I: infinite limits of integration
Type II: integrand has a discontinuity
lessons.teachingNotes: BC-exclusive. Students must write the limit notation—can't just 'plug in infinity.'

lessons.title: Accumulation Functions
concepts: g(x) = ∫ₐˣ f(t)dt as an accumulation function
Interpreting g, g', g'' from graph of f
Applications: displacement, total distance, total quantity
lessons.teachingNotes: This is the conceptual heart of integration. AP loves 'given the graph of f, describe g.'

modules.title: Unit 6 Checkpoint: Integration & Accumulation
modules.preview: Assess Riemann sums, FTC, antiderivatives, advanced techniques (by parts, partial fractions, improper), and accumulation

modules.title: Differential Equations
modules.preview: Slope fields, separation of variables, exponential growth/decay models
essentialQuestions: What does a slope field tell us about solutions to a differential equation without actually solving it?
How does separation of variables transform a differential equation into an integration problem?
How do exponential and logistic growth models arise from differential equations?

lessons.title: Slope Fields
concepts: Constructing slope fields from dy/dx expressions
Matching slope fields to differential equations
Sketching solution curves through given initial conditions
lessons.teachingNotes: Purely visual/conceptual. Students must match equations to fields and sketch solutions.

lessons.title: Separation of Variables
concepts: General solution (with +C) vs particular solution (use initial condition)
lessons.teachingNotes: The +C goes on one side only. Use initial condition to find particular solution.

lessons.title: Exponential Growth/Decay & Logistic Growth (BC)
concepts: Logistic: dy/dt = ky(1 − y/L), carrying capacity L
Logistic solution shape and fastest growth at L/2
lessons.teachingNotes: Logistic is BC-exclusive. Students must recognize the form and know the carrying capacity and inflection point.

lessons.title: Euler's Method (BC)
concepts: Numerical approximation of solutions to DEs
Step-by-step computation with given step size
lessons.teachingNotes: BC-exclusive. Straightforward computation, but students must be systematic.

modules.title: Unit 7 Checkpoint: Differential Equations
modules.preview: Assess slope fields, separation of variables, exponential/logistic models, and Euler's method

modules.title: Applications of Integration
modules.preview: Area between curves, volume by disk/washer and cross-sections, average value, motion applications
essentialQuestions: How does the integral compute area between curves, and why does the order of subtraction matter?
What geometric principle underlies disk/washer and cross-section volume methods?
What does the average value of a function mean, and how is it computed?

lessons.title: Area Between Curves
concepts: Switching integration variable when curves are functions of y

lessons.title: Volume: Disk & Washer Methods
concepts: Revolving around x-axis, y-axis, and other lines
Choosing dx vs dy based on axis of revolution

lessons.title: Volume by Cross-Sections
concepts: V = ∫A(x)dx where A(x) is cross-section area
Common shapes: squares, semicircles, equilateral triangles, isosceles right triangles
Base defined by region between curves

modules.title: Unit 8 Checkpoint: Applications of Integration
modules.preview: Assess area, volume, average value, and motion/accumulation applications

modules.title: Parametric, Polar, Vector-Valued Functions
modules.preview: Derivatives and integrals for parametric, polar, and vector-valued functions (BC-exclusive)
essentialQuestions: How do parametric equations represent motion, and how does dy/dx arise from dx/dt and dy/dt?
How does polar area differ from Cartesian area, and why does the formula use r²?
How do vector-valued functions generalize motion in the plane?

lessons.title: Polar Coordinates: Graphing, Slopes & Area
concepts: Polar-rectangular conversions: x = r cos θ, y = r sin θ
Common polar curves: circles, limaçons, roses, cardioids
Slope of polar curve: dy/dx = (r'sinθ + rcosθ)/(r'cosθ − rsinθ)
keyFormulas: x = r cos θ, y = r sin θ

lessons.title: Vector-Valued Functions
concepts: Position from velocity: r(t) = r(a) + ∫ₐᵗ v(s) ds

modules.title: Unit 9 Checkpoint: Parametric, Polar, Vector-Valued
modules.preview: Assess parametric derivatives, polar area, and vector-valued motion (BC-exclusive)

modules.title: Infinite Sequences & Series
modules.preview: Convergence tests, geometric/p-series, alternating series, Taylor/Maclaurin polynomials and error bounds (BC-exclusive)
essentialQuestions: How do we determine whether an infinite series converges or diverges?
How do Taylor and Maclaurin polynomials approximate functions, and how accurate is the approximation?
What is the interval of convergence for a power series, and why does it matter?

lessons.title: Sequences, Series, and Convergence Basics
concepts: Geometric series: converges when |r| < 1, sum = a/(1−r)
keyFormulas: Geometric series sum = a/(1 − r) when |r| < 1
lessons.teachingNotes: The nth-term test only proves DIVERGENCE, never convergence. Common student error.

lessons.title: Convergence Tests
concepts: Ratio test (most useful for factorials and exponentials)
keyFormulas: Ratio test: L = lim |a_{n+1}/a_n|; converges if L < 1, diverges if L > 1
lessons.teachingNotes: Build a decision tree: look at the series → choose the right test. Ratio test is the go-to for factorials.

lessons.title: Alternating Series & Error Bounds
concepts: Alternating series test: |aₙ| decreasing to 0 → converges
Alternating series error bound: |error| ≤ |first omitted term|
lessons.teachingNotes: The error bound is the simplest and most frequently tested on the AP exam.

lessons.title: Taylor & Maclaurin Polynomials
concepts: Taylor polynomial of degree n centered at x = a
Known Maclaurin series: eˣ, sin x, cos x, 1/(1−x)
Finding new series from known series (substitution, differentiation, integration)
lessons.teachingNotes: Students must MEMORIZE the four known series. Everything else is built from them.

lessons.title: Power Series & Interval of Convergence
concepts: Radius of convergence R (use ratio test)
Interval of convergence: check endpoints separately
Differentiation and integration of power series term by term
lessons.teachingNotes: Ratio test gives R. Then test EACH endpoint individually—they may behave differently.

lessons.title: Lagrange Error Bound
concepts: Finding M (max of |f⁽ⁿ⁺¹⁾| on the interval)
Using error bound to determine number of terms needed
lessons.teachingNotes: Lagrange is the hardest error bound but appears regularly. Practice finding M on specific intervals.

modules.title: Unit 10 Checkpoint: Sequences & Series
modules.preview: Assess convergence tests, Taylor/Maclaurin series, power series, and error bounds (BC-exclusive)

modules.title: Final Review & Exam Readiness
modules.preview: Comprehensive AP exam-format review with MC sets, FRQ practice, and error analysis
essentialQuestions: Which content areas are strongest, and which need targeted review?
Can I complete FRQs with full justification under time pressure?
Am I making careless errors, or are there genuine conceptual gaps?

lessons.title: Multiple Choice Practice Sets
concepts: Time management: ~2 min per MC question

lessons.title: Free Response Practice
concepts: FRQ scoring rubrics and point allocation
lessons.teachingNotes: FRQs award points for setup, computation, and justification separately. Students can earn partial credit.

lessons.title: Error Analysis & Targeted Review
concepts: Categorizing errors: conceptual vs computational vs notational

modules.title: AP Calculus BC Final Mastery Assessment
modules.preview: Comprehensive assessment covering all AP Calculus BC content in exam format
